originalInput: My snake plant has yellow mushy leaves

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'yellow', 'mushy' suggesting overwatering.
actions: Stop watering immediately - snake plants hate wet feet
Let soil dry completely (can go 2-3 weeks without water)
Repot with cactus/succulent mix
Ensure excellent drainage
diagnoses.eco_tip: Snake plants purify air better than most - they're natural air filters that work 24/7!

originalInput: My monstera is stretching and has small leaves

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'small leaves', 'stretching' suggesting insufficient light.
actions: Move to bright indirect light (near east/west window)
Avoid direct sun which burns leaves
Rotate plant weekly for even growth
Consider grow lights for dark spaces
diagnoses.eco_tip: Monstera aerial roots can be trained up moss poles - they'll grow stronger and develop bigger leaves!

originalInput: tulsi getting yellow
My tulsi is getting dry sometimes and the leaves are turning brown

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'dry', 'brown', 'brown edges' and symptoms: 'dry', 'brown' suggesting underwatering & dehydration.
actions: Water slowly and deeply until water drains from the bottom of the pot
Check soil moisture with your finger - water when top inch is dry
Increase watering frequency during hot weather and growing season
Consider using a self-watering pot or water reservoir system
Mist leaves daily to increase humidity around the plant
Move to a location with slightly higher humidity if possible
Use room temperature water to avoid shocking the roots
Water in the morning to allow excess moisture to evaporate during the day
diagnoses.eco_tip: Tulsi is considered sacred in many cultures and has natural air-purifying properties. Collect rainwater for watering - it's free, chemical-free, and contains beneficial minerals that tap water lacks!

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'dropping leaves' and symptoms: 'dry', 'brown' suggesting overwatering & root rot.
actions: Stop watering immediately and let soil dry out completely
Check for root rot - trim any black, mushy roots with clean scissors
Repot with fresh, well-draining soil mix (add perlite or sand)
Ensure pot has adequate drainage holes and isn't sitting in water
Use a terracotta pot for better moisture regulation
Water only when top 2 inches of soil are dry to the touch
Consider bottom watering method to encourage deep root growth
Improve air circulation around the plant to help soil dry faster
diagnoses.eco_tip: Tulsi is considered sacred in many cultures and has natural air-purifying properties. Collect rainwater for watering - it's free, chemical-free, and contains beneficial minerals that tap water lacks!

diagnoses.why: Detected keywords: 'brown' and symptoms: 'dry', 'brown' suggesting light problems & photosynthesis issues.
actions: Move to bright indirect light near an east or west-facing window
Avoid direct afternoon sun which can burn leaves
Rotate plant weekly for even growth and light distribution
Consider grow lights if natural light is insufficient
Gradually acclimate to new light conditions over 1-2 weeks
Use sheer curtains to filter intense direct sunlight
Supplement with LED grow lights during winter months
Monitor leaf color - dark green indicates too little light
diagnoses.eco_tip: Tulsi is considered sacred in many cultures and has natural air-purifying properties. Collect rainwater for watering - it's free, chemical-free, and contains beneficial minerals that tap water lacks!
